A1462806060866_0.5361432136942612.title: Girl Scout Trefoil Name Tag template

M1462803112364_0.7049194154331466.emlTemplate:
Hello Girl Scout Families,


Here are the details of our next meeting:

Date: Tue Jul 12, 2016 04:00 PM - 05:30 PM
Location:
Topic: Hear a Story Award pt. 1

You'll tell girls what this Journey is all about: How the stories they read or the TV shows and movies they watch can show them how girls live around the world â and give them ideas about how they can help others.

In this meeting, girls will:

  • Create a Team Passport that they'll use throughout the Journey
  • Play a game from another country
  • Explore how games and stories link Brownies to a wider world of girls
  • Be introduced to the Journey's Awards

Note to Volunteers:

The excitement and fast pace of running troop meetings for the first time can sometimes leave us tongue-tied. For that reason, scripting is included for guiding girls through a meeting; these "lines" are under the heading "SAY." However, you know your girls best. If you feel you don't need the script, do what makes sense for you and your girls.

Prepare Ahead

  • Get your badges here.
  • Make sure that you've gathered in advance all the supplies you'll need for the meeting. Feel free to substitute an item with something else if you can't get it.
  • A World of Girls is a flip book. Halfway through, the girls will need to flip the book over to read the second half. Please notice that the cover on one side has the Brownies dressed in regular clothes (Girls side). The cover on the other side has the Brownies dressed in clothing from other cultures (World side). When referring to different pages in the book in these meetings, each side will be noted as either Girls Side or World side.
  • Remind girls to bring the book to each meeting.

Get Help from Your Family and Friends Network

Your Family and Friends Network can include:

  • The Brownies' parents, aunts, uncles, older siblings, etc.
  • Other volunteers who have offered to help with the meeting

Ask your network to help:

  • Make snacks
  • Make name tags
  • Welcome girls to the meeting
  • Guide girls in one of the activities
  • Or just be ready to take care of small problems (spilled juice!), hand out art supplies (share the crayons, please!), act as cheerleaders (that Team Passport is awesome!), or help with clean up.

This first meeting is a special Journey kickoff! Invite your whole Network so everyone can join in the fun of starting Brownies on their adventure!

Award Connection

Brownies earn four awards on this Journey: 1) the Hear a Story Award, 2) the Change a Story Award, 3) the Tell a Story Award, and 4) the Better World for Girls! Award.

They will earn the first award, Hear a Story, by doing activities in Meetings 1 and 2. Brownies earn this award by learning about girls in other countries and finding out how they can use stories to get ideas for helping others.

Meeting Length

90 minutes

The times given for each activity will be different, depending on how many girls are in the troop.

Plus, girls may really enjoy a particular activity and want to continue past the allotted time. As much as possible, let them! That's part of keeping Girl Scouting girl-led!

And what do you do if you only have an hour for the meeting? Simply omit some of the activities.

Note that girls do need to do what are called the Award Activities in order to earn the Journey awards â but other than that, you can customize the meeting to fit the time you have and (always!) what girls want to do.


If you have any questions, or want to participate in this meeting, please contact me at


Thank you for supporting your 2-Brownie,


Sue

Troop 999104



Aids Included:



Form(s) Required

A1462807765067_0.37910015585453793.title: Hear a Story Find a Clue

B15OG03_0.9266777642864783.agenda: \[1^As Girls Arrive^5][2^Opening Ceremony: A Circle of Adventure^5][3^Introducing the Journey Awards^5][4^Team Passport^20][5^Games Around the Globe^15][6^Our Globe of Girls^15][7^Story and Snack Time^20][8^Closing Ceremony: A Great Place^5]

B15OG03_0.9266777642864783.name: Hear a Story Award pt. 1

A1462808069085_0.21873222580934593.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Name tags
  • Pens or pencils

Steps

Welcome girls to the meeting. Have each girl write her name on a name tag and then draw some fun decorations on it to make it her own. When they're done, stand in a circle and have the girls introduce themselves by saying their names.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Let girls decorate their name tags as they see fit — with swirls and flowers and balloons —whatever they want to draw.
A1462808069085_0.21873222580934593.name: As Girls Arrive

A1462808069089_0.7002874787448251.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Pita bread
  • Hummus
  • Cut vegetables for dipping
  • Fresh figs
  • Fig Newtons
  • Flying into Shali's Desert Home
  • Sticky Note

Steps

Flying into Shali's Desert Home is the first story in the girls' Journey book. Some girls may have read the story on their own, but may like listening to the story as they enjoy their snacks.

SAY:

  • We're going to hear a story about a girl who lives in the country of Jordan.
  • Would someone like to volunteer to find Jordan on the globe or map.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Give her some time to find Jordan. But, if she can't find it easily, you might guide her first to the Middle East and then help her zero in on the country.

Put a sticky note on Jordan so everyone can see where it is.

SAY:

  • Jordan is an Arab country in the Middle East that is a little smaller than Indiana.
  • Western Jordan is the only part of the country where people can grow food. In the east and the south, it's desert — those places get less than two inches of rain a year. (Do you know how much rain Indiana gets each year? Almost 41 inches!)
  • Arabic is the official language. People often greet each other by saying As-Salˉmu `Alaykum. That means peace be upon you. (It's pronounced Ahl sah-LAHM ah-LAY-koom.) The other person usually says Wa `Alaykum as-Salaam. That means and upon you be peace. (It's pronounced Wah ah-LAY-koom ahl sah-LAHM.)
  • When people in Jordan eat a meal together, it's a time of celebration.
  • And speaking of eating…this is a great moment to have some snacks! We're going to have some food that people eat in Jordan. Maybe some of you have tried these foods before, maybe not.

Have girls help pass out the food. For those who don't like or don't want to try the figs, offer them Fig Newtons.

As they eat, read Flying into Shali's Desert Home out loud. Short on time? Feel free to skip through the story or just tell it in your own words! Use different voices or add sound effects to amp up the fun factor!

When you're finished reading the story, SAY:

  • What did the Brownie friends learn about Shali's world?
  • What things do Campbell, Jamila, and Alejandra have in common with Shali?
  • What do you have in common with her?
  • What was most interesting to you about Shali's world?
  • What did you find most interesting about girls who live in Jordan?
  • What do you think it would be like to live there?
  • If a girl from Jordan visited you, what would you like to show here about where you live?
A1462808069089_0.7002874787448251.name: Story and Snack Time

A1462808069105_0.4499639219743633.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Girl Scout Promise and Law

Steps

Girls gather in a circle. Welcome them to the A World of Girls Journey.

SAY:

  • Can anyone tell us what a journey is? That's right, it's an adventure where you meet new people, see new places, learn new things, and have fun!
  • In Girl Scouts, Brownies get to go on a special Journey called A World of Girls.
  • How many of you like stories?Great! On this Journey, we'll hear, read, and talk about stories of women and girls from all around the world. You'll also explore your own world and girls from all parts of your life. You'll see that stories have clues in them about how to make the world a better place.
  • Now let's link arms and form a circle to say the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law together. Imagine you're forming a circle around the world. (Allow one of the girls to lead the promise and law)

When you're done with the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law,

SAY:

  • We've just said the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law, two wonderful things that unite Girl Scouts all around the world. Did you notice how the last line of the Law asks you to be a sister to every Girl Scout?
  • What do you think it means to be a sister to all the girls in our Brownie group, and all the Brownies around the world?

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Give girls a few minutes to come up with some answers. If they need some help, offer suggestions such as: caring about each other, learning about each other, having fun together, sharing ideas and feelings.
A1462808069105_0.4499639219743633.name: Opening Ceremony: A Circle of Adventure

A1462808069109_0.2978362414803911.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Journey Awards (for you)
  • A World of Girls, page 7 (for girls)

Steps

Give each girl a copy of A World of Girls, page 7.

SAY:

  • On this Journey, you'll earn four awards. Let's take a look at them. The awards are called:
  • Hear a Story
  • Change a Story
  • Tell a Story
  • Better World for Girls!
  • To earn these awards, you're going to play games from other countries, read some amazing stories, learn about other girls — just like you — who live all around the world, and come up with great ways to help other people. How does that sound?
  • How do you think you'll feel when you've earned these awards?
  • Great! We'll talk more about these awards as we travel along our Journey. But now let's get started!
A1462808069109_0.2978362414803911.name: Introducing the Journey Awards

A1462808069113_0.719816610467617.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Art supplies — paper, cardboard boxes, markers, crayons, colored pencils, glue, glitter glue, etc. Use whatever you have at hand or is easy to get! Bring something to cover the table with so it doesn't get dirty, and supplies with which to clean up (wipes, papers towels, etc.).

Steps

Have girls start planning what type of Team Passport they want to create to capture the story of what they do together on this Journey.

SAY:

  • We're going to create a Team Passport. A passport is a little booklet that lets you go places around the world. And each time you go to a new place, you get your passport stamped with the name of the place you visited. So, with those stamps in it, a passport tells the story of your travels.
  • Today we're going to start our Team Passport. It's going to tell the story of this Girl Scout Journey we're taking together and we're going to add to it at each meeting.
  • Let your imaginations run wild!
  • Let's talk about a few ways you can create a Team Passport:
  • You could decorate a box with maps or postcards and fill it with items you've made or chosen that reflect what you did on this Journey.
  • You could make a photo album or photo display. At each meeting, different girls would take turns being the group photographer and then you can post photos from the previous meeting and write captions for them.
  • You could create a diorama and design the background of it, and then add toy figures, cutouts, or other items each time we get together.
  • Or how about making a mural? Each time we meet, you could decorate pieces of paper with stickers, rubber stampings, drawings, writing, pictures, photos — or whatever you choose. The panels could be taped together as the Journey progresses, so that you can see your story taking shape.
  • Once decided, let girls start creating their Team Passport for a few minutes.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Encourage girls to let their imaginations run wild when they make their Team Passport. This activity isn't about creating great art — it's about having fun together!
A1462808069113_0.719816610467617.name: Team Passport

A1462808069125_0.16845736804524303.activityDescription:
Materials

  • For Banyoka: objects that can be used as obstacles (desks, chairs, books or boxes, traffic cones, large balls)

Steps

Get girls to name some games they enjoy and shout out why they like them.

SAY:

  • All around the world, girls like to play games, especially games in which they move around.
  • You can get to know other people by playing games together. And active games help you stay healthy and fit.
  • By playing games from around the world, you also get to see what girls in other places like to do.
  • Now it's time to let girls burn off some Brownie energy by playing a game from another country!

You can teach girls how to play Banyoka or choose a game from another country that you (or someone in your Friends and Family Network) knows how to play.

Banyoka is an obstacle-course game played in Zambia and Zaire. It can be played indoors or out. Ask someone from your Friends and Family Network to set up the obstacle course in advance. To play the game:

  • Create an obstacle course by placing the large objects you brought to the meeting around the room (or outside).
  • Form two teams of roughly equal numbers of girls. (It's okay if one team has an extra member if you have an odd number of girls.)
  • Each team becomes a snake: Girls sit on the floor or ground, one right behind the other, with their hands on the shoulders of the girl in front.
  • Each team scootches along, moving around or over the obstacles while staying connected. The first team to get around its set of obstacles wins.

Variations:

  • Girls form their snake by standing with arms linked.
  • They form one team and play against the clock.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Let girls decide which variation of this game they'd like to play.
A1462808069125_0.16845736804524303.name: Games Around the Globe

A1462808069137_0.328110702666745.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Globe or world map
  • Sticky notes or slips of paper
  • Tape
  • Pencil or pen
  • Yarn (thread or string work, too)
  • Flip chart or whiteboard
  • OPTIONAL: computer with Internet access

Steps

After playing Banyoka, point out Zambia and Zaire on a globe or world map. (If they played a game from another country, point out that country instead.)

SAY:

  • Now you know one way that girls in Zambia and Zaire have fun. That's a connection you have with them. If they came here to visit, we could all have fun playing Banyoka together.
  • We all have different connections to different countries around the world.
  • I'm connected to the country of _______, because my grandparents came from there.
  • I'm connected to __________, because I visited there in college.
  • I'm connected to __________, because I love __________ food.
  • Now it's your turn. Think of a way you are connected to another country. Write it on a sticky note (or slip of paper), and put the paper on that country.

Once girls have put their papers on the globe or map, give them pieces of yarn. Have them tape one end to the country they're connected to and the other end to their hometown.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Let girls try to find countries on their own before stepping in to help. (You could also gently suggest that the girls help each other — Brownie teamwork!)

SAY:

  • Look at all the connections we have with other countries — and other girls — around the world! And we'll keep adding more at each meeting as we do our A World of Girls Journey.
  • In fact, let's start right now. There are other Brownies, just like you, all around the world. Where do you think they live?

Let girls shout out their answers — don't be afraid of a little rumpus! That's the sound of fun happening!

SAY:

  • Girl Scouts or Girl Guides are in more than 145 countries. That means you have a really big sisterhood of girls all around the world!
  • What is one thing you'd like to learn about Girl Scouts in another country? What's one thing you'd like Girl Scouts in other countries to know about you?

As girls shout out their answers, write what they say on a flip chart or whiteboard so girls see their ideas being collected.

SAY:

  • WAGGGS is a group for all Girl Guides and Girl Scouts around the world. It's like a big sisterhood — and since you're Girl Scout Brownies, you belong to it, too!

OPTIONAL: Go online and show girls the website of the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts.
A1462808069137_0.328110702666745.name: Our Globe of Girls

A1462808069149_0.5354278864427137.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Journey Poem

Steps

Ask girls to stand up, then read each line of the following poem and have girls repeat it.

Our Journey began today

We reached into worlds faraway

We'll reach even farther

On our adventure to come

As we hear stories about girls

Read stories about girls

And share stories about girls

Like you, and you, and you, and me!

Our world of girls is a great place to be!

While reading the poem, encourage girls to clap, match body movements to the words, stomp their feet, jump — whatever makes this more fun for them!

When girls have finished reciting the poem,

SAY:

  • We're at the end of our meeting. For next time, have some fun thinking about stories and some girl characters you know from movies, TV, or books that we can talk about!

Ask a girl to end the ceremony by starting the friendship squeeze.
A1462808069149_0.5354278864427137.name: Closing Ceremony: A Great Place

  • What do you think it means to be a sister to all the girls in our Brownie group, and all the Brownies around the world?

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Give girls a few minutes to come up with some answers. If they need some help, offer suggestions such as: caring about each other, learning about each other, having fun together, sharing ideas and feelings.

Activity 3 : Introducing the Journey Awards

Time Allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Journey Awards (for you)
  • A World of Girls, page 7 (for girls)

Steps

Give each girl a copy of A World of Girls, page 7.

SAY:

  • On this Journey, you'll earn four awards. Let's take a look at them. The awards are called:
  • Hear a Story
  • Change a Story
  • Tell a Story
  • Better World for Girls!
  • To earn these awards, you're going to play games from other countries, read some amazing stories, learn about other girls — just like you — who live all around the world, and come up with great ways to help other people. How does that sound?
  • How do you think you'll feel when you've earned these awards?
  • Great! We'll talk more about these awards as we travel along our Journey. But now let's get started!

Activity 4 : Team Passport

Time Allotment

20 minutes

Materials

  • Art supplies — paper, cardboard boxes, markers, crayons, colored pencils, glue, glitter glue, etc. Use whatever you have at hand or is easy to get! Bring something to cover the table with so it doesn't get dirty, and supplies with which to clean up (wipes, papers towels, etc.).

Steps

Have girls start planning what type of Team Passport they want to create to capture the story of what they do together on this Journey.

SAY:

  • We're going to create a Team Passport. A passport is a little booklet that lets you go places around the world. And each time you go to a new place, you get your passport stamped with the name of the place you visited. So, with those stamps in it, a passport tells the story of your travels.
  • Today we're going to start our Team Passport. It's going to tell the story of this Girl Scout Journey we're taking together and we're going to add to it at each meeting.
  • Let your imaginations run wild!
  • Let's talk about a few ways you can create a Team Passport:
  • You could decorate a box with maps or postcards and fill it with items you've made or chosen that reflect what you did on this Journey.
  • You could make a photo album or photo display. At each meeting, different girls would take turns being the group photographer and then you can post photos from the previous meeting and write captions for them.
  • You could create a diorama and design the background for it, and then add toy figures, cutouts, or other items each time we get together.
  • Or how about making a mural? Each time we meet, you could decorate pieces of paper with stickers, rubber stampings, drawings, writing, pictures, photos — or whatever you choose. The panels could be taped together as the Journey progresses, so that you can see your story taking shape.
  • Once decided, let girls start creating their Team Passport for a few minutes.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Encourage girls to let their imaginations run wild when they make their Team Passport. This activity isn't about creating great art — it's about having fun together!

Activity 5 : Games Around the Globe

Time Allotment

15 minutes

Materials

  • For Banyoka: objects that can be used as obstacles (desks, chairs, books or boxes, traffic cones, large balls)

Steps

Get girls to name some games they enjoy and shout out why they like them.

SAY:

  • All around the world, girls like to play games, especially games in which they move around.
  • You can get to know other people by playing games together. And active games help you stay healthy and fit.
  • By playing games from around the world, you also get to see what girls in other places like to do.
  • Now it's time to let girls burn off some Brownie energy by playing a game from another country!

You can teach girls how to play Banyoka or choose a game from another country that you (or someone in your Friends and Family Network) knows how to play.

Banyoka is an obstacle-course game played in Zambia and Zaire. It can be played indoors or out. Ask someone from your Friends and Family Network to set up the obstacle course in advance. To play the game:

  • Create an obstacle course by placing the large objects you brought to the meeting around the room (or outside).
  • Form two teams of roughly equal numbers of girls. (It's okay if one team has an extra member if you have an odd number of girls.)
  • Each team becomes a snake: Girls sit on the floor or ground, one right behind the other, with their hands on the shoulders of the girl in front.
  • Each team scootches along, moving around or over the obstacles while staying connected. The first team to get around its set of obstacles wins.

Variations:

  • Girls form their snake by standing with arms linked.
  • They form one team and play against the clock.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Let girls decide which variation of this game they'd like to play.

Activity 6 : Our Globe of Girls

Time Allotment

15 minutes

Materials

  • Globe or world map
  • Sticky notes or slips of paper
  • Tape
  • Pencil or pen
  • Yarn (thread or string work, too)
  • Flip chart or whiteboard
  • OPTIONAL: computer with Internet access

Steps

After playing Banyoka, point out Zambia and Zaire on a globe or world map. (If they played a game from another country, point out that country instead.)

SAY:

  • Now you know one way that girls in Zambia and Zaire have fun. That's a connection you have with them. If they came here to visit, we could all have fun playing Banyoka together.
  • We all have different connections to different countries around the world.
  • I'm connected to the country of _______, because my grandparents came from there.
  • I'm connected to __________, because I visited there in college.
  • I'm connected to __________, because I love __________ food.
  • Now it's your turn. Think of a way you are connected to another country. Write it on a sticky note (or slip of paper), and put the paper on that country.

Once girls have put their papers on the globe or map, give them pieces of yarn. Have them tape one end to the country they're connected to and the other end to their hometown.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Let girls try to find countries on their own before stepping in to help. (You could also gently suggest that the girls help each other — Brownie teamwork!)

SAY:

  • Look at all the connections we have with other countries — and other girls — around the world! And we'll keep adding more at each meeting as we do our A World of Girls Journey.
  • In fact, let's start right now. There are other Brownies, just like you, all around the world. Where do you think they live?

Let girls shout out their answers — don't be afraid of a little rumpus! That's the sound of fun happening!

SAY:

  • Girl Scouts or Girl Guides are in more than 145 countries. That means you have a really big sisterhood of girls all around the world!
  • What is one thing you'd like to learn about Girl Scouts in another country? What's one thing you'd like Girl Scouts in other countries to know about you?

As girls shout out their answers, write what they say on a flip chart or whiteboard so girls see their ideas being collected.

SAY:

  • WAGGGS is a group for all Girl Guides and Girl Scouts around the world. It's like a big sisterhood — and since you're Girl Scout Brownies, you belong to it, too!

OPTIONAL: Go online and show girls the website of the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts.

Activity 7 : Story and Snack Time

Time Allotment

20 minutes

Materials

  • Pita bread
  • Hummus
  • Cut vegetables for dipping
  • Fresh figs
  • Fig Newtons
  • Flying into Shali's Desert Home
  • Sticky Note

Steps

Flying into Shali's Desert Home is the first story in the girls' Journey book. Some girls may have read the story on their own, but may like listening to the story as they enjoy their snacks.

SAY:

  • We're going to hear a story about a girl who lives in the country of Jordan.
  • Would someone like to volunteer to find Jordan on the globe or map.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Give her some time to find Jordan. But, if she can't find it easily, you might guide her first to the Middle East and then help her zero in on the country.

Put a sticky note on Jordan so everyone can see where it is.

SAY:

  • Jordan is an Arab country in the Middle East that is a little smaller than Indiana.
  • Western Jordan is the only part of the country where people can grow food. In the east and the south, it's desert — those places get less than two inches of rain a year. (Do you know how much rain Indiana gets each year? Almost 41 inches!)
  • Arabic is the official language. People often greet each other by saying As-Salˉmu `Alaykum. That means peace be upon you. (It's pronounced Ahl sah-LAHM ah-LAY-koom.) The other person usually says Wa `Alaykum as-Salaam. That means and upon you be peace. (It's pronounced Wah ah-LAY-koom ahl sah-LAHM.)
  • When people in Jordan eat a meal together, it's a time of celebration.
  • And speaking of eating…this is a great moment to have some snacks! We're going to have some food that people eat in Jordan. Maybe some of you have tried these foods before, maybe not.

Have girls help pass out the food. For those who don't like or don't want to try the figs, offer them Fig Newtons.

As they eat, read Flying into Shali's Desert Home out loud. Short on time? Feel free to skip through the story or just tell it in your own words! Use different voices or add sound effects to amp up the fun factor!

When you're finished reading the story, SAY:

  • What did the Brownie friends learn about Shali's world?
  • What things do Campbell, Jamila, and Alejandra have in common with Shali?
  • What do you have in common with her?
  • What was most interesting to you about Shali's world?
  • What did you find most interesting about girls who live in Jordan?
  • What do you think it would be like to live there?
  • If a girl from Jordan visited you, what would you like to show here about where you live?

Activity 8 : Closing Ceremony: A Great Place

Time Allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Journey Poem

Steps

Ask girls to stand up, then read each line of the following poem and have girls repeat it.

Our Journey began today

We reached into worlds faraway

We'll reach even farther

On our adventure to come

As we hear stories about girls

Read stories about girls

And share stories about girls

Like you, and you, and you, and me!

Our world of girls is a great place to be!

While reading the poem, encourage girls to clap, match body movements to the words, stomp their feet, jump — whatever makes this more fun for them!

When girls have finished reciting the poem,

SAY:

  • We're at the end of our meeting. For next time, have some fun thinking about stories and some girl characters you know from movies, TV, or books that we can talk about!

Ask a girl to end the ceremony by starting the friendship squeeze.

A1462808069105_0.4499639219743633.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Girl Scout Promise and Law

Steps

Girls gather in a circle. Welcome them to the A World of Girls Journey.

SAY:

  • Can anyone tell us what a journey is? That's right, it's an adventure where you meet new people, see new places, learn new things, and have fun!
  • In Girl Scouts, Brownies get to go on a special Journey called A World of Girls.
  • How many of you like stories?Great! On this Journey, we'll hear, read, and talk about stories of women and girls from all around the world. You'll also explore your own world and girls from all parts of your life. You'll see that stories have clues in them about how to make the world a better place.
  • Now let's link arms and form a circle to say the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law together. Imagine you're forming a circle around the world. (Allow one of the girls to lead the promise and law)

When you're done with the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law,

SAY:

  • We've just said the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law, two wonderful things that unite Girl Scouts all around the world. Did you notice how the last line of the Law asks you to be a sister to every Girl Scout?
  • What do you think it means to be a sister to all the girls in our Brownie group, and all the Brownies around the world?

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Give girls a few minutes to come up with some answers. If they need some help, offer suggestions such as: caring about each other, learning about each other, having fun together, sharing ideas and feelings.

A1462808069149_0.5354278864427137.name: Closing Ceremony: A Great Place

overview.str:
You'll tell girls what this Journey is all about: How the stories they read or the TV shows and movies they watch can show them how girls live around the world — and give them ideas about how they can help others.

In this meeting, girls will:

  • Create a Team Passport that they'll use throughout the Journey
  • Play a game from another country
  • Explore how games and stories link Brownies to a wider world of girls
  • Be introduced to the Journey's Awards

Note to Volunteers:

The excitement and fast pace of running troop meetings for the first time can sometimes leave us tongue-tied. For that reason, scripting is included for guiding girls through a meeting; these "lines" are under the heading "SAY." However, you know your girls best. If you feel you don't need the script, do what makes sense for you and your girls.

Prepare Ahead

  • Get your badges here.
  • Make sure that you've gathered in advance all the supplies you'll need for the meeting. Feel free to substitute an item with something else if you can't get it.
  • A World of Girls is a flip book. Halfway through, the girls will need to flip the book over to read the second half. Please notice that the cover on one side has the Brownies dressed in regular clothes (Girls side). The cover on the other side has the Brownies dressed in clothing from other cultures (World side). When referring to different pages in the book in these meetings, each side will be noted as either Girls Side or World side.
  • Remind girls to bring the book to each meeting.

Get Help from Your Family and Friends Network

Your Family and Friends Network can include:

  • The Brownies' parents, aunts, uncles, older siblings, etc.
  • Other volunteers who have offered to help with the meeting

Ask your network to help:

  • Make snacks
  • Make name tags
  • Welcome girls to the meeting
  • Guide girls in one of the activities
  • Or just be ready to take care of small problems (spilled juice!), hand out art supplies (share the crayons, please!), act as cheerleaders (that Team Passport is awesome!), or help with clean up.

This first meeting is a special Journey kickoff! Invite your whole Network so everyone can join in the fun of starting Brownies on their adventure!

Award Connection

Brownies earn four awards on this Journey: 1) the Hear a Story Award, 2) the Change a Story Award, 3) the Tell a Story Award, and 4) the Better World for Girls! Award.

They will earn the first award, Hear a Story, by doing activities in Meetings 1 and 2. Brownies earn this award by learning about girls in other countries and finding out how they can use stories to get ideas for helping others.

Meeting Length

90 minutes

The times given for each activity will be different, depending on how many girls are in the troop.

Plus, girls may really enjoy a particular activity and want to continue past the allotted time. As much as possible, let them! That's part of keeping Girl Scouting girl-led!

And what do you do if you only have an hour for the meeting? Simply omit some of the activities.

Note that girls do need to do what are called the Award Activities in order to earn the Journey awards — but other than that, you can customize the meeting to fit the time you have and (always!) what girls want to do.

detailed_x0020_activity_x0020_plan.str:
Activity 1 : As Girls Arrive

Time Allotment

5 Minutes

Materials

  • Name tags
  • Pens or pencils

Steps

Welcome girls to the meeting. Have each girl write her name on a name tag and then draw some fun decorations on it to make it her own. When they're done, stand in a circle and have the girls introduce themselves by saying their names.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Let girls decorate their name tags as they see fit — with swirls and flowers and balloons —whatever they want to draw.

Activity 2 : Opening Ceremony: A Circle of Adventure

Time Allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Girl Scout Promise and Law

Steps

Girls gather in a circle. Welcome them to the A World of Girls Journey.

SAY:

  • Can anyone tell us what a journey is? That's right, it's an adventure where you meet new people, see new places, learn new things, and have fun!
  • In Girl Scouts, Brownies get to go on a special Journey called A World of Girls.
  • How many of you like stories?Great! On this Journey, we'll hear, read, and talk about stories of women and girls from all around the world. You'll also explore your own world and girls from all parts of your life. You'll see that stories have clues in them about how to make the world a better place.
  • Now let's link arms and form a circle to say the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law together. Imagine you're forming a circle around the world.

When you're done with the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law,

SAY:

  • We've just said the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law, two wonderful things that unite Girl Scouts all around the world. Did you notice how the last line of the Law asks you to be a sister to every Girl Scout?
  • What do you think it means to be a sister to all the girls in our Brownie group, and all the Brownies around the world?

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Give girls a few minutes to come up with some answers. If they need some help, offer suggestions such as: caring about each other, learning about each other, having fun together, sharing ideas and feelings.

Activity 3 : Introducing the Journey Awards

Time Allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Journey Awards (for you)
  • A World of Girls, page 7 (for girls)

Steps

Give each girl a copy of A World of Girls, page 7.

SAY:

  • On this Journey, you'll earn four awards. Let's take a look at them. The awards are called:
  • Hear a Story
  • Change a Story
  • Tell a Story
  • Better World for Girls!
  • To earn these awards, you're going to play games from other countries, read some amazing stories, learn about other girls — just like you — who live all around the world, and come up with great ways to help other people. How does that sound?
  • How do you think you'll feel when you've earned these awards?
  • Great! We'll talk more about these awards as we travel along our Journey. But now let's get started!

Activity 4 : Team Passport

Time Allotment

20 minutes

Materials

  • Art supplies — paper, cardboard boxes, markers, crayons, colored pencils, glue, glitter glue, etc. Use whatever you have at hand or is easy to get! Bring something to cover the table with so it doesn't get dirty, and supplies with which to clean up (wipes, papers towels, etc.).

Steps

Have girls start planning what type of Team Passport they want to create to capture the story of what they do together on this Journey.

SAY:

  • We're going to create a Team Passport. A passport is a little booklet that lets you go places around the world. And each time you go to a new place, you get your passport stamped with the name of the place you visited. So, with those stamps in it, a passport tells the story of your travels.
  • Today we're going to start our Team Passport. It's going to tell the story of this Girl Scout Journey we're taking together and we're going to add to it at each meeting.
  • Let your imaginations run wild!
  • Let's talk about a few ways you can create a Team Passport:
  • You could decorate a box with maps or postcards and fill it with items you've made or chosen that reflect what you did on this Journey.
  • You could make a photo album or photo display. At each meeting, different girls would take turns being the group photographer and then you can post photos from the previous meeting and write captions for them.
  • You could create a diorama and design the background for it, and then add toy figures, cutouts, or other items each time we get together.
  • Or how about making a mural? Each time we meet, you could decorate pieces of paper with stickers, rubber stampings, drawings, writing, pictures, photos — or whatever you choose. The panels could be taped together as the Journey progresses, so that you can see your story taking shape.
  • Once decided, let girls start creating their Team Passport for a few minutes.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Encourage girls to let their imaginations run wild when they make their Team Passport. This activity isn't about creating great art — it's about having fun together!

Activity 5 : Games Around the Globe

Time Allotment

15 minutes

Materials

  • For Banyoka: objects that can be used as obstacles (desks, chairs, books or boxes, traffic cones, large balls)

Steps

Get girls to name some games they enjoy and shout out why they like them.

SAY:

  • All around the world, girls like to play games, especially games in which they move around.
  • You can get to know other people by playing games together. And active games help you stay healthy and fit.
  • By playing games from around the world, you also get to see what girls in other places like to do.
  • Now it's time to let girls burn off some Brownie energy by playing a game from another country!

You can teach girls how to play Banyoka or choose a game from another country that you (or someone in your Friends and Family Network) knows how to play.

Banyoka is an obstacle-course game played in Zambia and Zaire. It can be played indoors or out. Ask someone from your Friends and Family Network to set up the obstacle course in advance. To play the game:

  • Create an obstacle course by placing the large objects you brought to the meeting around the room (or outside).
  • Form two teams of roughly equal numbers of girls. (It's okay if one team has an extra member if you have an odd number of girls.)
  • Each team becomes a snake: Girls sit on the floor or ground, one right behind the other, with their hands on the shoulders of the girl in front.
  • Each team scootches along, moving around or over the obstacles while staying connected. The first team to get around its set of obstacles wins.

Variations:

  • Girls form their snake by standing with arms linked.
  • They form one team and play against the clock.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Let girls decide which variation of this game they'd like to play.

Activity 6 : Our Globe of Girls

Time Allotment

15 minutes

Materials

  • Globe or world map
  • Sticky notes or slips of paper
  • Tape
  • Pencil or pen
  • Yarn (thread or string work, too)
  • Flip chart or whiteboard
  • OPTIONAL: computer with Internet access

Steps

After playing Banyoka, point out Zambia and Zaire on a globe or world map. (If they played a game from another country, point out that country instead.)

SAY:

  • Now you know one way that girls in Zambia and Zaire have fun. That's a connection you have with them. If they came here to visit, we could all have fun playing Banyoka together.
  • We all have different connections to different countries around the world.
  • I'm connected to the country of _______, because my grandparents came from there.
  • I'm connected to __________, because I visited there in college.
  • I'm connected to __________, because I love __________ food.
  • Now it's your turn. Think of a way you are connected to another country. Write it on a sticky note (or slip of paper), and put the paper on that country.

Once girls have put their papers on the globe or map, give them pieces of yarn. Have them tape one end to the country they're connected to and the other end to their hometown.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Let girls try to find countries on their own before stepping in to help. (You could also gently suggest that the girls help each other — Brownie teamwork!)

SAY:

  • Look at all the connections we have with other countries — and other girls — around the world! And we'll keep adding more at each meeting as we do our A World of Girls Journey.
  • In fact, let's start right now. There are other Brownies, just like you, all around the world. Where do you think they live?

Let girls shout out their answers — don't be afraid of a little rumpus! That's the sound of fun happening!

SAY:

  • Girl Scouts or Girl Guides are in more than 145 countries. That means you have a really big sisterhood of girls all around the world!
  • What is one thing you'd like to learn about Girl Scouts in another country? What's one thing you'd like Girl Scouts in other countries to know about you?

As girls shout out their answers, write what they say on a flip chart or whiteboard so girls see their ideas being collected.

SAY:

  • WAGGGS is a group for all Girl Guides and Girl Scouts around the world. It's like a big sisterhood — and since you're Girl Scout Brownies, you belong to it, too!

OPTIONAL: Go online and show girls the website of the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts.

Activity 7 : Story and Snack Time

Time Allotment

20 minutes

Materials

  • Pita bread
  • Hummus
  • Cut vegetables for dipping
  • Fresh figs
  • Fig Newtons
  • Flying into Shali's Desert Home
  • Sticky Note

Steps

Flying into Shali's Desert Home is the first story in the girls' Journey book. Some girls may have read the story on their own, but may like listening to the story as they enjoy their snacks.

SAY:

  • We're going to hear a story about a girl who lives in the country of Jordan.
  • Would someone like to volunteer to find Jordan on the globe or map.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Give her some time to find Jordan. But, if she can't find it easily, you might guide her first to the Middle East and then help her zero in on the country.

Put a sticky note on Jordan so everyone can see where it is.

SAY:

  • Jordan is an Arab country in the Middle East that is a little smaller than Indiana.
  • Western Jordan is the only part of the country where people can grow food. In the east and the south, it's desert — those places get less than two inches of rain a year. (Do you know how much rain Indiana gets each year? Almost 41 inches!)
  • Arabic is the official language. People often greet each other by saying As-Salˉmu `Alaykum. That means peace be upon you. (It's pronounced Ahl sah-LAHM ah-LAY-koom.) The other person usually says Wa `Alaykum as-Salaam. That means and upon you be peace. (It's pronounced Wah ah-LAY-koom ahl sah-LAHM.)
  • When people in Jordan eat a meal together, it's a time of celebration.
  • And speaking of eating…this is a great moment to have some snacks! We're going to have some food that people eat in Jordan. Maybe some of you have tried these foods before, maybe not.

Have girls help pass out the food. For those who don't like or don't want to try the figs, offer them Fig Newtons.

As they eat, read Flying into Shali's Desert Home out loud. Short on time? Feel free to skip through the story or just tell it in your own words! Use different voices or add sound effects to amp up the fun factor!

When you're finished reading the story, SAY:

  • What did the Brownie friends learn about Shali's world?
  • What things do Campbell, Jamila, and Alejandra have in common with Shali?
  • What do you have in common with her?
  • What was most interesting to you about Shali's world?
  • What did you find most interesting about girls who live in Jordan?
  • What do you think it would be like to live there?
  • If a girl from Jordan visited you, what would you like to show here about where you live?

Activity 8 : Closing Ceremony: A Great Place

Time Allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Journey Poem

Steps

Ask girls to stand up, then read each line of the following poem and have girls repeat it.

Our Journey began today

We reached into worlds faraway

We'll reach even farther

On our adventure to come

As we hear stories about girls

Read stories about girls

And share stories about girls

Like you, and you, and you, and me!

Our world of girls is a great place to be!

While reading the poem, encourage girls to clap, match body movements to the words, stomp their feet, jump — whatever makes this more fun for them!

When girls have finished reciting the poem,

SAY:

  • We're at the end of our meeting. For next time, have some fun thinking about stories and some girl characters you know from movies, TV, or books that we can talk about!

Ask a girl to end the ceremony by starting the friendship squeeze.

Welcome girls to the meeting. Have each girl write her name on a name tag and then draw some fun decorations on it to make it her own. When they're done, stand in a circle and have the girls introduce themselves by saying their names.

overview.str:
You'll tell girls what this Journey is all about: How the stories they read or the TV shows and movies they watch can show them how girls live around the world — and give them ideas about how they can help others.

In this meeting, girls will:

  • Create a Team Passport that they'll use throughout the Journey
  • Play a game from another country
  • Explore how games and stories link Brownies to a wider world of girls
  • Be introduced to the Journey's Awards

Note to Volunteers:

The excitement and fast pace of running troop meetings for the first time can sometimes leave us tongue-tied. For that reason, scripting is included for guiding girls through a meeting; these "lines" are under the heading "SAY." However, you know your girls best. If you feel you don't need the script, do what makes sense for you and your girls.

Prepare Ahead

  • Get your badges here.
  • Make sure that you've gathered in advance all the supplies you'll need for the meeting. Feel free to substitute an item with something else if you can't get it.
  • A World of Girls is a flip book. Halfway through, the girls will need to flip the book over to read the second half. Please notice that the cover on one side has the Brownies dressed in regular clothes (Girls side). The cover on the other side has the Brownies dressed in clothing from other cultures (World side). When referring to different pages in the book in these meetings, each side will be noted as either Girls Side or World side.
  • Remind girls to bring the book to each meeting.

Get Help from Your Family and Friends Network

Your Family and Friends Network can include:

  • The Brownies' parents, aunts, uncles, older siblings, etc.
  • Other volunteers who have offered to help with the meeting

Ask your network to help:

  • Make snacks
  • Make name tags
  • Welcome girls to the meeting
  • Guide girls in one of the activities
  • Or just be ready to take care of small problems (spilled juice!), hand out art supplies (share the crayons, please!), act as cheerleaders (that Team Passport is awesome!), or help with clean up.

This first meeting is a special Journey kickoff! Invite your whole Network so everyone can join in the fun of starting Brownies on their adventure!

Award Connection

Brownies earn four awards on this Journey: 1) the Hear a Story Award, 2) the Change a Story Award, 3) the Tell a Story Award, and 4) the Better World for Girls! Award.

They will earn the first award, Hear a Story, by doing activities in Meetings 1 and 2. Brownies earn this award by learning about girls in other countries and finding out how they can use stories to get ideas for helping others.

Meeting Length

90 minutes

The times given for each activity will be different, depending on how many girls are in the troop.

Plus, girls may really enjoy a particular activity and want to continue past the allotted time. As much as possible, let them! That's part of keeping Girl Scouting girl-led!

And what do you do if you only have an hour for the meeting? Simply omit some of the activities.

Note that girls do need to do what are called the Award Activities in order to earn the Journey awards — but other than that, you can customize the meeting to fit the time you have and (always!) what girls want to do.

detailed_x0020_activity_x0020_plan.str:
Activity 1 : As Girls Arrive

Time Allotment

5 Minutes

Materials

  • Name tags
  • Pens or pencils

Steps

Welcome girls to the meeting. Have each girl write her name on a name tag and then draw some fun decorations on it to make it her own. When they're done, stand in a circle and have the girls introduce themselves by saying their names.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Let girls decorate their name tags as they see fit — with swirls and flowers and balloons —whatever they want to draw.

Activity 2 : Opening Ceremony: A Circle of Adventure

Time Allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Girl Scout Promise and Law

Steps

Girls gather in a circle. Welcome them to the A World of Girls Journey.

SAY:

  • Can anyone tell us what a journey is? That's right, it's an adventure where you meet new people, see new places, learn new things, and have fun!
  • In Girl Scouts, Brownies get to go on a special Journey called A World of Girls.
  • How many of you like stories?Great! On this Journey, we'll hear, read, and talk about stories of women and girls from all around the world. You'll also explore your own world and girls from all parts of your life. You'll see that stories have clues in them about how to make the world a better place.
  • Now let's link arms and form a circle to say the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law together. Imagine you're forming a circle around the world.

When you're done with the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law,

SAY:

  • We've just said the Girl Scout Promise and the Girl Scout Law, two wonderful things that unite Girl Scouts all around the world. Did you notice how the last line of the Law asks you to be a sister to every Girl Scout?
  • What do you think it means to be a sister to all the girls in our Brownie group, and all the Brownies around the world?

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Give girls a few minutes to come up with some answers. If they need some help, offer suggestions such as: caring about each other, learning about each other, having fun together, sharing ideas and feelings.

Activity 3 : Introducing the Journey Awards

Time Allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Journey Awards (for you)
  • A World of Girls, page 7 (for girls)

Steps

Give each girl a copy of A World of Girls, page 7.

SAY:

  • On this Journey, you'll earn four awards. Let's take a look at them. The awards are called:
  • Hear a Story
  • Change a Story
  • Tell a Story
  • Better World for Girls!
  • To earn these awards, you're going to play games from other countries, read some amazing stories, learn about other girls — just like you — who live all around the world, and come up with great ways to help other people. How does that sound?
  • How do you think you'll feel when you've earned these awards?
  • Great! We'll talk more about these awards as we travel along our Journey. But now let's get started!

Activity 4 : Team Passport

Time Allotment

20 minutes

Materials

  • Art supplies — paper, cardboard boxes, markers, crayons, colored pencils, glue, glitter glue, etc. Use whatever you have at hand or is easy to get! Bring something to cover the table with so it doesn't get dirty, and supplies with which to clean up (wipes, papers towels, etc.).

Steps

Have girls start planning what type of Team Passport they want to create to capture the story of what they do together on this Journey.

SAY:

  • We're going to create a Team Passport. A passport is a little booklet that lets you go places around the world. And each time you go to a new place, you get your passport stamped with the name of the place you visited. So, with those stamps in it, a passport tells the story of your travels.
  • Today we're going to start our Team Passport. It's going to tell the story of this Girl Scout Journey we're taking together and we're going to add to it at each meeting.
  • Let your imaginations run wild!
  • Let's talk about a few ways you can create a Team Passport:
  • You could decorate a box with maps or postcards and fill it with items you've made or chosen that reflect what you did on this Journey.
  • You could make a photo album or photo display. At each meeting, different girls would take turns being the group photographer and then you can post photos from the previous meeting and write captions for them.
  • You could create a diorama and design the background for it, and then add toy figures, cutouts, or other items each time we get together.
  • Or how about making a mural? Each time we meet, you could decorate pieces of paper with stickers, rubber stampings, drawings, writing, pictures, photos — or whatever you choose. The panels could be taped together as the Journey progresses, so that you can see your story taking shape.
  • Once decided, let girls start creating their Team Passport for a few minutes.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Encourage girls to let their imaginations run wild when they make their Team Passport. This activity isn't about creating great art — it's about having fun together!

Activity 5 : Games Around the Globe

Time Allotment

15 minutes

Materials

  • For Banyoka: objects that can be used as obstacles (desks, chairs, books or boxes, traffic cones, large balls)

Steps

Get girls to name some games they enjoy and shout out why they like them.

SAY:

  • All around the world, girls like to play games, especially games in which they move around.
  • You can get to know other people by playing games together. And active games help you stay healthy and fit.
  • By playing games from around the world, you also get to see what girls in other places like to do.
  • Now it's time to let girls burn off some Brownie energy by playing a game from another country!

You can teach girls how to play Banyoka or choose a game from another country that you (or someone in your Friends and Family Network) knows how to play.

Banyoka is an obstacle-course game played in Zambia and Zaire. It can be played indoors or out. Ask someone from your Friends and Family Network to set up the obstacle course in advance. To play the game:

  • Create an obstacle course by placing the large objects you brought to the meeting around the room (or outside).
  • Form two teams of roughly equal numbers of girls. (It's okay if one team has an extra member if you have an odd number of girls.)
  • Each team becomes a snake: Girls sit on the floor or ground, one right behind the other, with their hands on the shoulders of the girl in front.
  • Each team scootches along, moving around or over the obstacles while staying connected. The first team to get around its set of obstacles wins.

Variations:

  • Girls form their snake by standing with arms linked.
  • They form one team and play against the clock.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Let girls decide which variation of this game they'd like to play.

Activity 6 : Our Globe of Girls

Time Allotment

15 minutes

Materials

  • Globe or world map
  • Sticky notes or slips of paper
  • Tape
  • Pencil or pen
  • Yarn (thread or string work, too)
  • Flip chart or whiteboard
  • OPTIONAL: computer with Internet access

Steps

After playing Banyoka, point out Zambia and Zaire on a globe or world map. (If they played a game from another country, point out that country instead.)

SAY:

  • Now you know one way that girls in Zambia and Zaire have fun. That's a connection you have with them. If they came here to visit, we could all have fun playing Banyoka together.
  • We all have different connections to different countries around the world.
  • I'm connected to the country of _______, because my grandparents came from there.
  • I'm connected to __________, because I visited there in college.
  • I'm connected to __________, because I love __________ food.
  • Now it's your turn. Think of a way you are connected to another country. Write it on a sticky note (or slip of paper), and put the paper on that country.

Once girls have put their papers on the globe or map, give them pieces of yarn. Have them tape one end to the country they're connected to and the other end to their hometown.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Let girls try to find countries on their own before stepping in to help. (You could also gently suggest that the girls help each other — Brownie teamwork!)

SAY:

  • Look at all the connections we have with other countries — and other girls — around the world! And we'll keep adding more at each meeting as we do our A World of Girls Journey.
  • In fact, let's start right now. There are other Brownies, just like you, all around the world. Where do you think they live?

Let girls shout out their answers — don't be afraid of a little rumpus! That's the sound of fun happening!

SAY:

  • Girl Scouts or Girl Guides are in more than 145 countries. That means you have a really big sisterhood of girls all around the world!
  • What is one thing you'd like to learn about Girl Scouts in another country? What's one thing you'd like Girl Scouts in other countries to know about you?

As girls shout out their answers, write what they say on a flip chart or whiteboard so girls see their ideas being collected.

SAY:

  • WAGGGS is a group for all Girl Guides and Girl Scouts around the world. It's like a big sisterhood — and since you're Girl Scout Brownies, you belong to it, too!

OPTIONAL: Go online and show girls the website of the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts.

Activity 7 : Story and Snack Time

Time Allotment

20 minutes

Materials

  • Pita bread
  • Hummus
  • Cut vegetables for dipping
  • Fresh figs
  • Fig Newtons
  • Flying into Shali's Desert Home
  • Sticky Note

Steps

Flying into Shali's Desert Home is the first story in the girls' Journey book. Some girls may have read the story on their own, but may like listening to the story as they enjoy their snacks.

SAY:

  • We're going to hear a story about a girl who lives in the country of Jordan.
  • Would someone like to volunteer to find Jordan on the globe or map.

Keep It Girl-Led Tip

Give her some time to find Jordan. But, if she can't find it easily, you might guide her first to the Middle East and then help her zero in on the country.

Put a sticky note on Jordan so everyone can see where it is.

SAY:

  • Jordan is an Arab country in the Middle East that is a little smaller than Indiana.
  • Western Jordan is the only part of the country where people can grow food. In the east and the south, it's desert — those places get less than two inches of rain a year. (Do you know how much rain Indiana gets each year? Almost 41 inches!)
  • Arabic is the official language. People often greet each other by saying As-Salˉmu `Alaykum. That means peace be upon you. (It's pronounced Ahl sah-LAHM ah-LAY-koom.) The other person usually says Wa `Alaykum as-Salaam. That means and upon you be peace. (It's pronounced Wah ah-LAY-koom ahl sah-LAHM.)
  • When people in Jordan eat a meal together, it's a time of celebration.
  • And speaking of eating…this is a great moment to have some snacks! We're going to have some food that people eat in Jordan. Maybe some of you have tried these foods before, maybe not.

Have girls help pass out the food. For those who don't like or don't want to try the figs, offer them Fig Newtons.

As they eat, read Flying into Shali's Desert Home out loud. Short on time? Feel free to skip through the story or just tell it in your own words! Use different voices or add sound effects to amp up the fun factor!

When you're finished reading the story, SAY:

  • What did the Brownie friends learn about Shali's world?
  • What things do Campbell, Jamila, and Alejandra have in common with Shali?
  • What do you have in common with her?
  • What was most interesting to you about Shali's world?
  • What did you find most interesting about girls who live in Jordan?
  • What do you think it would be like to live there?
  • If a girl from Jordan visited you, what would you like to show here about where you live?

Activity 8 : Closing Ceremony: A Great Place

Time Allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Journey Poem

Steps

Ask girls to stand up, then read each line of the following poem and have girls repeat it.

Our Journey began today

We reached into worlds faraway

We'll reach even farther

On our adventure to come

As we hear stories about girls

Read stories about girls

And share stories about girls

Like you, and you, and you, and me!

Our world of girls is a great place to be!

While reading the poem, encourage girls to clap, match body movements to the words, stomp their feet, jump — whatever makes this more fun for them!

When girls have finished reciting the poem,

SAY:

  • We're at the end of our meeting. For next time, have some fun thinking about stories and some girl characters you know from movies, TV, or books that we can talk about!

Ask a girl to end the ceremony by starting the friendship squeeze.

meeting_x0020_short_x0020_description.str: Girls examine how stories in film, television, and print show girls’ lives around the world through games and activities.

yearPlan.desc: On this Journey, Daisies travel the country living the values of the Girl Scout Law; the flowers explore the natural world around them, learning what's local and why that's important. Girls can earn three awards as they experience what's great about their own region and learn to use their own special skills to help people and Planet Earth.
yearPlan.name: Daisy Journey Year: Between Earth and Sky

A1462825150305_0.3216029726136995.content:
Thanks to our friends at Bold Idea, Girl Scout Cadettes will join a team to learn computer science and coding for a pretty cool activity! Supported by mentors, students will complete coding challenges and a mobile app project together that helps their community. As a result, students will build skills in computational thinking, problem solving and teamwork. No prior coding experience required.

 

Badge: Netiquette

Cost: $200

Open to Families: No

STEM: Yes

Note: This is a bi-weekly event beginning February 20, 2016 until May 14, 2016. Girls will also earn the STEM Center and "T" patches.

For additional information, please email Robyn Brown at robyn@boldidea.org or call (972)765-1943.
A1462825150305_0.3216029726136995.name: ideaSpark: Learn Coding

A1462825252166_0.3269253292568839.content:
Call to Schedule your Date & Time:

The Frontiers of Flight Museum offers STEM-based week-long summer camps for grades levels 1-12. The camps offered cover fields in aviation, aerodynamics, space, rocketry, robotics, and UAV (Drones). Girl Scouts can earn the STEM Center patch and two STEM letter patches by participating in camp and completing a list of activities. Come tinker, explore, and create at the Frontiers of Flight Museum!

Cost: $200/week for members; $225/week for non-members

Open to Families: No

STEM: Yes

Note: Monday - Friday times include 9 a.m. - 4 p.m. (Extended Hours: 8 a.m - 9 a.m and 4 p.m. - 5:30 p.m.)

Website:  www.flightmuseum.com

For registration or additional information, please email Dr. Jason Treadway at treadway@flightmuseum.com or call (214)350-3654.
A1462825252166_0.3269253292568839.name: Aviation & Space Summer Camps

D15DP12_0.5488736241656922.blurb: Girls earn Count It Up leaf.
D15DP12_0.5488736241656922.name: Count It Up

A1462825005149_0.8420383919528189.activityDescription:
Time Allotment

15 minutes

Materials

  • Play money, $4 for each girl
  • Meet the Cookies flash cards from previous activity (lay out on a table or tape up on a poster board so girls can see them)
  • At least 12 real or fake boxes of cookies to hand out in pretend sales game

SAY:

Now that you know what kind of Girl Scout Cookies you like best, I'll bet you want to buy one. Let's pretend you are the customers buying one box of your favorite cookie.

Let's say one box of cookies costs $4. Count out the money on the table in front of you and find at least $4. You may have more than that, and that's OK. I can give you change. Then, one by one, come up and buy your cookie. If you need help counting out money, I'll help you.

Act as the salesperson and give girls sales tips as each comes up to make their purchase. Use these lines on different girls. Have girls listen to each transaction so they can pick up sales tips:

  • Greet each one hello.
  • Ask if she would like to buy Girl Scout Cookies today.
  • Ask if she has a favorite cookie. Tell her what your favorite kind is.
  • Tell her that there are some great new cookie types she might want to try.
  • Tell her that running a cookie business helps girls do great things.
  • Tell her that one special thing we hope to do with our cookie earnings this year is… go camping (or whatever you want to say here).
  • Give girl change if needed.
  • Thank each girl for her purchase.

Keep it Girl-Led Tip

If girls want to switch roles and play salesperson, too, that's great! If girls want to buy two boxes of cookies, that's OK, too.

When role-play is finished, SAY:

What did you learn about what you might tell your customers? (Say please and thank you. Suggest a cookie. Tell your customer what you will do with your earnings.)
A1462825005149_0.8420383919528189.name: Cost of Cookies

A1462825005160_0.4703289830204055.activityDescription:
Time Allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Paper
  • Crayons, markers

SAY:

Welcome, Daisies! In today's meeting, you'll learn about Girl Scout Cookies and how you can sell them to customers. But first, draw your favorite cookie. It can be a Girl Scout Cookie or any other type of cookie you love to eat.
A1462825005160_0.4703289830204055.name: As Girls Arrive

A1462825005163_0.4598259715148154.activityDescription:
Time Allotment

10 minutes

Materials

  • Girl Scout Promise and Law
  • Meet the Cookies flash cards, prepared in advance

Steps

Gather girls in a circle. Welcome them to the Count It Up leaf meeting. Read the Girl Scout Promise and Law, either have girls repeat each line or say it by heart.

SAY:

First let's share your cookie drawings. Name your favorites!

Did anyone draw a type of Girl Scout cookie? If so, what kind is it?

When girls have shared, SAY:

Who doesn't love cookies, right? We're all lucky we get to sell them. And Girl Scout cookies are the most delicious in the world!

Let's play cookie flash card. I'll show you the cookie type and you describe it for me. Don't worry if you don't know. We'll figure it out together!

One by one, show the flash cards of each of the cookie types. If girls need help, SAY:

Thin Mints: These are round, mint-flavored cookies with a delicious chocolatey coating.

Samoas/Caramel deLites: There are two names for this cookie: they are caramel and toasted-coconut covered cookies.

Peanut Butter Patties/Tagalongs: Also two names for this round cookie that is filled with peanut butter and has a rich chocolate coating.

Trefoils/Shortbread: A traditional cookie with the Girl Scout symbol

Do-si-dos/Peanut Butter Sandwich: These are crisp and crunchy oatmeal on the outside and creamy peanut butter on the inside

Lemonades: These have tangy lemon icing on shortbread cookies. Yum!

Savannah Smiles: These are lemon-flavored cookies dusted with powdered sugar.

Thanks-A-Lot: This is a shortbread cookie with fudge on the bottom.

Dulce de Leche: These are sweet, bite-sized treats with milk caramel chips.

Cranberry Citrus Crisps: This crispy cookie is made with whole grain and is full of bits of cranberry and citrus flavor.

Chocolate Chip Shortbread: There are chocolate chips inside yummy shortbread cookies.

Thank U Berry Much: This cookie has white fudge and bits of cranberry together!

Did anyone think there were so many yummy kinds of Girl Scout Cookies? After hearing about these, which ones do you think would be your favorite? Did you already have a favorite?

After girls answer, SAY:

It's good to let your customers what kind of Girl Scout Cookies you like, especially if they're having trouble choosing.
A1462825005163_0.4598259715148154.name: Opening Ceremony

A1462825005166_0.8336644448050322.activityDescription:
Time Allotment

15 minutes

Materials

  • Healthy snack items
  • A black and white poster based on the Cookie Goal Meter
  • Crayons

Steps

As girls are enjoying their snacks, SAY:

How many boxes of cookies do you and your Daisy friends want to sell? That's called your goal.

Share the goal poster with girls. Then SAY:

This is what a goal chart might look like. At the top, you would put your goal number — that's the number of boxes of cookies you and your troop hope to sell.

Underneath, you can write in each week and how many you actual sell every time we meet.

When you're done with your snack, go ahead and start coloring this Cookie Goal Meter poster and start dreaming about how many boxes you want to sell!
A1462825005166_0.8336644448050322.name: Snack Chat & Cookie Goal

A1462825005168_0.8570149217724115.activityDescription:
Time Allotment

10 minutes

Materials

  • Paper
  • Pen or pencil

Steps

SAY:

Remember when I was selling cookies earlier, I mentioned that running our Cookie Business helps girls do great things?

One of those great things is that Girl Scouts help make the world a better place. As you go through Girl Scouting, you'll come up with a Take Action Project. Taking Action means you find a place or people that need something. Then you come up with a way to help them. Then you put your plan into action by helping them.

This might mean using some of your cookie earnings to help buy supplies for animals at a shelter; or by using your earnings to buy supplies to draw posters showing people how to save water. There are so many things you can do!

I'll make a list of your ideas so when you are ready to come up with a Take Action Project, I can remind you about them!
A1462825005168_0.8570149217724115.name: Take Action Pause

A1462825005173_0.43790870528604897.activityDescription:
Time allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Count It Up leaf, enough for each girl

Steps

Have girls sit on the floor and form a Friendship Circle.

SAY:

  • Do you remember some of the types of Girl Scout Cookies? Call out the ones you remember!
  • Did you have fun figuring out how to count the money for your box of cookies? Were you able to buy more than one box?
  • Do you have an idea of how many boxes you want to sell by yourself? As a troop?

Congratulations! Now that you know about the cost of cookies, what kinds there are, and what it means to set a sales goal, you've earned your Count it Up leaf!

Give a leaf to each girl, then SAY:

Wear it to know how your cookie money adds up!
A1462825005173_0.43790870528604897.name: Closing Ceremony

overview.str:
Note to Volunteers:

The excitement and fast pace of running troop meetings for the first time can sometimes leave us tongue-tied. For that reason, scripting is included for guiding girls through a meeting; these "lines" are under the heading "SAY." However, you're the expert. If you feel you don't need the script, do what makes sense for you and your girls.

Prepare Ahead

  • Get your badges here.
  • Talk to anyone helping you about what they will do at this meeting
  • Activity 2: Print out copies (color, if possible) of Meet the Cookies. Cut out each type and paste it on a separate index card to create Meet the Cookies flash cards.
  • Activity 3: Collect at least 12 empty recycled boxes to make sample Girl Scout Cookie boxes. (If real Girl Scout Cookie boxes aren't available, use those instead.)
  • Activity 4: Draw or print out a black and white copy of the Cookie Goal Meter on a large-size poster board.

Get Help from Your Friends and Family Network

  • See if anyone wants to lead or support an activity or meeting.

Award Connection

  • In this session, girls will earn their Count It Up leaf.

Meeting Length

60 minutes

The times given for each activity will be different, depending on how many girls are in the troop.

Plus, girls may really enjoy a particular activity and want to continue past the allotted time. As much as possible, let them! That's part of keeping Girl Scouting girl-led!

Activity 3 : Cost of Cookies

Time Allotment

15 minutes

Materials

  • At least 12 real or fake boxes of cookies to hand out in pretend sales game

Now that you know what kind of Girl Scout Cookies you like best, I'll bet you want to buy one. Let's pretend you are the customers buying one box of your favorite cookie.

Let's say one box of cookies costs $4. Count out the money on the table in front of you and find at least $4. You may have more than that, and that's OK. I can give you change. Then, one by one, come up and buy your cookie. If you need help counting out money, I'll help you.

Act as the salesperson and give girls sales tips as each comes up to make their purchase. Use these lines on different girls. Have girls listen to each transaction so they can pick up sales tips:

  • Greet each one hello.
  • Ask if she would like to buy Girl Scout Cookies today.
  • Ask if she has a favorite cookie. Tell her what your favorite kind is.
  • Tell her that there are some great new cookie types she might want to try.
  • Tell her that running a cookie business helps girls do great things.
  • Tell her that one special thing we hope to do with our cookie earnings this year is… go camping (or whatever you want to say here).
  • Give girl change if needed.
  • Thank each girl for her purchase.

Keep it Girl-Led Tip

If girls want to switch roles and play salesperson, too, that's great! If girls want to buy two boxes of cookies, that's OK, too.

When role-play is finished, SAY:

What did you learn about what you might tell your customers? (Say please and thank you. Suggest a cookie. Tell your customer what you will do with your earnings.)

Activity 4 : Snack Chat & Cookie Goal

Time Allotment

15 minutes

Materials

  • Healthy snack items
  • A black and white poster based on the Cookie Goal Meter
  • Crayons

Steps

As girls are enjoying their snacks, SAY:

How many boxes of cookies do you and your Daisy friends want to sell? That's called your goal.

Share the goal poster with girls. Then SAY:

This is what a goal chart might look like. At the top, you would put your goal number — that's the number of boxes of cookies you and your troop hope to sell.

Underneath, you can write in each week and how many you actual sell every time we meet.

When you're done with your snack, go ahead and start coloring this Cookie Goal Meter poster and start dreaming about how many boxes you want to sell!

Activity 5 : Take Action Pause

Time Allotment

10 minutes

Materials

  • Paper
  • Pen or pencil

Steps

SAY:

Remember when I was selling cookies earlier, I mentioned that running our Cookie Business helps girls do great things?

One of those great things is that Girl Scouts help make the world a better place. As you go through Girl Scouting, you'll come up with a Take Action Project. Taking Action means you find a place or people that need something. Then you come up with a way to help them. Then you put your plan into action by helping them.

This might mean using some of your cookie earnings to help buy supplies for animals at a shelter; or by using your earnings to buy supplies to draw posters showing people how to save water. There are so many things you can do!

I'll make a list of your ideas so when you are ready to come up with a Take Action Project, I can remind you about them!

Activity 6 : Closing Ceremony

Time allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Count It Up leaf, enough for each girl

Steps

Have girls sit on the floor and form a Friendship Circle.

SAY:

  • Do you remember some of the types of Girl Scout Cookies? Call out the ones you remember!
  • Did you have fun figuring out how to count the money for your box of cookies? Were you able to buy more than one box?
  • Do you have an idea of how many boxes you want to sell by yourself? As a troop?

Congratulations! Now that you know about the cost of cookies, what kinds there are, and what it means to set a sales goal, you've earned your Count it Up leaf!

Give a leaf to each girl, then SAY:

Wear it to know how your cookie money adds up!

materials.str:
Activity 1: As Girls Arrive

  • Paper
  • Crayons, markers

Activity 2: Opening Ceremony

  • Girl Scout Promise and Law
  • Meet the Cookies flash cards, prepared in advance

Activity 3: Cost of Cookies

  • Play money, $4 for each girl
  • Meet the Cookies flash cards from previous activity (lay out on a table or tape up on a poster board so girls can see them)
  • At least 12 real or fake boxes of cookies to hand out in pretend sales game

Activity 4: Snack Chat & Cookie Goal

  • Healthy snack items
  • A black and white poster based on the Cookie Goal Meter
  • Crayons

Activity 5: Take Action Pause

  • Paper
  • Pen or pencil

Activity 6: Closing Ceremony

  • Count It Up leaf, enough for each girl
